metadata.synopsis: In Cazador's Palace (Either Mansion part or Dungeon part)

75.speaker: Astarion
75.context: InternalNodeContext: Flag: In Cazador's Palace (ie. not in the dungeon where the ritual is taking place)

65.speaker: Astarion
65.text: I can face anything now. Let's get back to the hunt.
65.context: NodeContext: Invigorated, enjoying his power as a vampire lord

97.speaker: Astarion
97.context: NodeContext: Tired, weary - the low after killing Cazador but not ascending.

72.speaker: Astarion
72.text: So this is it. I'm home.

17.speaker: Astarion
17.text: There's the same fading carpet, the same tasteless art...

14.speaker: Astarion
14.text: Nothing's changed, but gods, everything feels different.

10.speaker: Astarion
10.text: We have everything we need to open the ballroom door, so let's not waste time talking.
10.context: InternalNodeContext: Player hasn't got through the Ballroom door yet, but they know they need to. They have the key and can translate the inscription.

87.speaker: Astarion
87.text: Cazador's hiding somewhere behind that door, and I'm going to find him.

23.speaker: Astarion
23.text: Two centuries walking these halls and I've never once seen the ballroom door locked.

94.speaker: Astarion
94.text: Cazador doesn't want anything going wrong tonight.

22.speaker: Astarion
22.text: Cazador's skulking somewhere beneath us, in this 'defiled chapel' the others mentioned.

93.speaker: Astarion
93.text: We just have to find the entrance. Then he'll be mine.

85.speaker: Astarion
85.text: Cazador's nearby, I can feel it. He'll have some secret room or tunnel, I'm sure of it.

11.speaker: Astarion
11.text: It does feel strange, breaking into your own home. Especially if murder's on your mind.

100.speaker: Astarion
100.text: Then again, this is hardly the strangest thing we've done together.

43.speaker: Astarion
43.text: Although it could be the most satisfying.

0.speaker: Astarion
0.context: NodeContext: Astarion thinking about the time he slept with the player

40.speaker: Player
40.text: Are the servants charmed, like the guards in the tower?

63.speaker: Astarion
63.text: Oh no, it's much worse than that.

3.speaker: Astarion
3.text: They're fanatics, here of their own free will and utterly devoted to Cazador.

110.speaker: Astarion
110.text: Each one came to our door and begged to be given his 'eternal gift'. They're sure he'll turn them if they serve him well enough.

47.speaker: Astarion
47.text: You'd almost feel sorry for the poor, deluded souls.

42.speaker: Astarion
42.text: But they're idiots who brought this on themselves, so... don't.

109.speaker: Player
109.text: Why are the servants so... odd?

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Who's this 'Godey'? Why does he have the key?

84.speaker: Astarion
84.text: He's Cazador's skeletal right hand - he kept us in line when 'master' didn't feel like torturing us himself.

41.speaker: Astarion
41.text: If Cazador was going to trust anyone to lock the doors behind him, it'd be that rattling old carcass.

38.speaker: Astarion
38.text: Godey kept us in kennels downstairs. The master ruled everywhere else, but they were his domain.

81.speaker: Astarion
81.text: If my dear siblings were right, Cazador's hiding somewhere below the palace.

95.speaker: Astarion
95.text: After so many years, I would have spotted any secret tunnels out here.

77.speaker: Astarion
77.text: The only place that was off-limits to us was his study. If the entrance is anywhere, it'll be there - through the ballroom.

2.speaker: Astarion
2.text: If Cazador's hiding anywhere, it'll be behind the huge, locked doors covered in secret writing.

114.speaker: Astarion
114.text: Our old kennelmaster Godey will have a key, but the writing? I've no idea how to read that.

89.speaker: Astarion
89.text: The signet ring should unlock the ballroom door, but only if we can read the inscription.

107.speaker: Astarion
107.text: And I don't know about you, but it's pure gibberish to me.

39.speaker: Astarion
39.text: We need to unlock the ballroom door, which we can't do without a key.

8.speaker: Astarion
8.text: Our dear kennelmaster Godey will be lurking downstairs with one. I doubt he'll want to share, though.

71.speaker: Astarion
71.text: Well, I was thinking first we find Cazador. And then we kill Cazador.

104.speaker: Astarion
104.text: That's about it, really. We can workshop the details as we go.

37.speaker: Player
37.text: Are you sure about this? You don't have to face him.

90.speaker: Astarion
90.text: Oh, I've never been less sure of anything. But if I don't face him now, I never will.

91.speaker: Astarion
91.text: I'll spend the rest of my life running, watching the shadows, never feeling safe.

49.speaker: Astarion
49.text: No, this has to happen. Here and now.

18.speaker: Astarion
18.text: Also, there's the small matter of all that power I can steal from the bastard. So that'll be nice.

68.speaker: Player
68.text: I need to ask you something else.

98.speaker: Astarion
98.context: InternalNodeContext: Flag: In the dungeon underneath Cazador's Palace (access via Elevator in Cazador's Palace or the Sewers)

19.speaker: Astarion
19.text: Not now! Not when Cazador's finally mine.

54.speaker: Astarion
54.text: Hurry, to his coffin! It's time to end this.

112.speaker: Astarion
112.text: Cazador's healing in his coffin. This is the moment - he's mine.

88.speaker: Astarion
88.text: This is all so grand. To think it was just sitting here, lurking under the floor.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: What is this place? A temple? A prison?

5.speaker: Astarion
5.text: It could be either, both, or something else entirely.

33.speaker: Astarion
33.text: Whatever this place is, he kept it secret for a reason. And his secrets always had a sting to them.

30.speaker: Astarion
30.text: Now we just need to see what lies at the heart of this place.

122.speaker: Player
122.text: Do you think he built this dungeon just for the ritual?

9.speaker: Player
9.text: Do you think he built this dungeon just for the ritual?

116.speaker: Astarion
116.text: I don't know, it feels older than that. Who knows how old...

35.speaker: Astarion
35.text: But Cazador will want a grand space for his Ascension. A venue like this feels perfect.

79.speaker: Player
79.text: Do you think he built this dungeon just for the ritual?

20.speaker: Player
20.text: You really had no idea this was here?

80.speaker: Astarion
80.text: Of course not - it's not like he boasted about his secret lift.

58.speaker: Astarion
58.text: But it does make sense. He'd want somewhere grand for his Ascension. This seems perfect.

61.speaker: Astarion
61.text: Just keep your eyes open. We could find anything down here.

44.speaker: Astarion
44.text: Well? You clearly want to say something.
44.context: NodeContext: A little defense - this is soon after seeing the prisoners.

86.speaker: Player
86.text: I just want to know if you'll actually set those prisoners free.

15.speaker: Player
15.text: What do you plan to do with all those prisoners?

59.speaker: Astarion
59.text: I'm not sure, I've been weighing my options.

64.speaker: Astarion
64.text: On the one hand, they're the key to my unlocking eternal power and freedom. On the other...

96.speaker: Astarion
96.text: Well. It's my fault they're here.

6.speaker: Astarion
6.text: Yes, it was Cazador's command, I had no choice. But...

70.speaker: Player
70.text: You should free them. You owe them that.

13.speaker: Astarion
13.text: And what am I owed? What about the injustices I've suffered - am I not entitled to anything?

7.speaker: Astarion
7.text: All that matters now is killing Cazador. I've earned that, if nothing else.

53.speaker: Astarion
53.text: We can deal with the prisoners when the time is right. After all, they're not going anywhere.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: All right, but what's best for you?

118.speaker: Astarion
118.text: That will very much depend on what happens once I face Cazador.

117.speaker: Astarion
117.text: But I have to find him before I can face him. So let's focus on that, shall we?

121.speaker: Player
121.text: I'm sure you'll make the right decision.

67.speaker: Astarion
67.text: I'm sure I will. Whatever the hells that might be.

12.speaker: Astarion
12.text: I... I don't know. I thought they were dead for so long.

50.speaker: Astarion
50.text: I could feel guilty, happy in the knowledge there was nothing I could have done differently. I could never have saved them.

21.speaker: Astarion
21.text: But now... now there's a choice to make.
21.context: NodeContext: heavy topic, weighing up difficult decisions

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Will you save the children of Ulma's tribe like you promised?

25.speaker: Astarion
25.text: That is a complicated question. I was so sure they were dead.

73.speaker: Player
73.text: Do you think the children from Ulma's tribe are still alive?

125.speaker: Astarion
125.text: 'Alive'? No. But animated? Yes, I'm sure they are.

108.speaker: Astarion
108.text: If Cazador turned the victims we brought him to spawn, he'll have done the same to the children. With glee, I imagine.

83.speaker: Astarion
83.text: But let's not forget why we're here - Cazador needs to die. Everything else comes second.

78.speaker: Player
78.text: I just can't believe you delivered children to Cazador...

34.speaker: Astarion
34.text: I had no say in the matter - it was my master's command.

55.speaker: Player
55.text: You're brooding about the prisoners. Stop it.

4.speaker: Astarion
4.text: You're right, I am. How could I not, after coming face-to-face with the ghosts of my past?

16.speaker: Astarion
16.text: Actually, ghosts would have been preferable over starving vampire spawn.

102.speaker: Astarion
102.text: But you're right, this isn't the time. Cazador is our objective - nothing can distract me from that.

124.speaker: Player
124.text: You don't have to face Cazador. We can just leave.

66.speaker: Astarion
66.text: No, we can't. Not after seeing those wretches in the cells. If I flee now, he wins.

48.speaker: Astarion
48.text: And once we find him... well, let's hope fate is on our side.

105.speaker: Astarion
105.text: Quiet! Anyone could be lurking nearby.
